author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles plans to compete in the balance beam, her last possible event in Tokyo.
description: The decision comes as she had skipped three other apparatus finals and the individual all-around.
content: TOKYO — Simone Biles, the headliner of the Tokyo Olympics for Team U.S.A., is not done just yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate in the infrastructure bill: $73 billion for the electric grid but less for electric vehicles and lead pipes.
description: The bill falls short of the transformational climate measures that President Biden has requested.
content: The infrastructure package has some substantial investments aimed at addressing climate change, but it is far from the transformational package that President Biden had sought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: A California Today Farewell
description: Monday: Reflecting on almost three years of chronicling the biggest news in the Golden State.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senators finish writing bipartisan infrastructure bill in rare weekend session.
description: Democratic leaders say the Senate will vote on the $1 trillion infrastructure bill and a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint before leaving Washington for the August recess.
content: The Senate is expected to advance a $1 trillion infrastructure bill this week after lawmakers spent the weekend finalizing the sprawling measure, which would fund roads, bridges and dams as well as broadband and climate resiliency projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor Board Official Backs Union Challenge on Amazon Vote
description: A hearing officer for the National Labor Relations Board found that Amazon illegally discouraged organizing at an Alabama warehouse. The company can appeal to block a new election.
content: A hearing officer of the National Labor Relations Board has recommended that the board throw out a union election at an Amazon warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., where results announced in early April showed workers rejecting a union by a more than two-to-one ratio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: One sport has gifted Indonesia all its Olympic golds. The streak continues in Tokyo.
description: A women’s doubles badminton victory was the first gold for Indonesia in Tokyo and the eighth in the country’s Olympic history.
content: Indonesia has won Olympic gold in only one sport: badminton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Three Sharply Observed Books Showcase the Enduring Appeal of Memoirs About Dealing With Disease
description: Three new books about affliction — Fred D’Aguiar’s “Year of Plagues,” Jan Grue’s “I Live a Life Like Yours” and James Tate Hill’s “Blind Man’s Bluff” — have a lot to say about desire, pain, depression and many other topics.
content: Nietzsche’s maxim, that whatever doesn’t kill you makes you stronger, has a corollary in the book world: What doesn’t kill you will be the topic of your memoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Home Depot, SoulCycle and other businesses tighten pandemic restrictions.
description: Equinox and Walmart are requiring some employees to be vaccinated. Home Depot and Lowes are reinstating mask requirements for workers.
content: With the coronavirus spreading across the country and hospitalizations rising again, and public health officials warning that the Delta variant carries new risks even for vaccinated people, big businesses are rethinking their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Matthew Goldstein
title: Administration Seeks to Blunt Effects From End of Eviction Moratorium
description: After the expiration of the moratorium over the weekend, the White House called on state and local governments to protect renters and sought to speed the flow of federal aid.
content: WASHINGTON — With the federal moratorium on evictions having expired over the weekend, the White House on Monday sought to limit the impact, demanding that states speed up disbursement of billions of dollars in bottled-up rental aid while pleading with local governments to enact their own extensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Acrobatics Aren’t Confined to the Olympics
description: Tokyo and Washington confound expectations.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I think I’ve been … wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
title: Americans Suffer Pandemic Whiplash as Leaders Struggle With Changing Virus
description: An evolving virus and 18 months of ever-changing pandemic messaging have left Americans angry, exhausted and skeptical of public health advice.
content: WASHINGTON — A week of public health reversals from the White House and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has left Americans with pandemic whiplash, sowing confusion about coronavirus vaccines and mask-wearing as the Delta variant upends what people thought they knew about how to stay safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Germany Will Offer Vaccine Booster Shots Starting in September
description: In rich countries, the momentum is growing for giving additional doses to the fully vaccinated, though many experts say the focus should be on getting first doses to people around the world.
content: BERLIN — As concerns grow over the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus, Germany on Monday became the biggest Western country yet to announce that it will offer vaccine booster shots to a wide range of people considered potentially vulnerable, adding to growing momentum in rich nations to give additional shots to fully vaccinated people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: How a Cuban Émigré Became a Polish Volleyball God
description: Wilfredo León left Cuba to see how far his high-flying talents could take him. Having starred as a pro in Italy, he now wants to win gold for Poland.
content: TOKYO — There are roughly 11,000 athletes at the Tokyo Olympics, each with a story. Here is one of them, about the world’s greatest volleyball player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen, Melodie Jeng and Brent Murray
title: A Wall Street Dressing Down: Always. Be. Casual.
description: As workers return to the financial district, longstanding dress codes have been relaxed. Right now, almost anything goes. Even jeans.
content: The suits are returning to the office. In chinos. And sneakers. And ballet flats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A brush fire in Hawaii exceeds 40,000 acres and prompts evacuations.
description: Residents were allowed to return home on Sunday but could be required to evacuate again if conditions worsen.
content: A fast-moving brush fire that has burned more than 40,000 acres on the Big Island of Hawaii prompted mandatory evacuations over the weekend, the authorities said. Although residents were allowed to return home on Sunday, they could be required to evacuate again if weather conditions worsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Maalouf
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Monday includes beach volleyball and track and field.
description: NBC will also air replays of gymnastics event finals for both men and women.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Monday, including beach volleyball quarterfinals and key track and field events. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is Ken Burns Taking Up Too Much Space? He Doesn’t Think So.
description: The documentarian responds to the PBS letter and why he is ‘very troubled’ by the Anthony Bourdain A.I. voice-over.
content: From “deepfaking” Anthony Bourdain’s voice to reconstructing a re-education camp in Xinjiang — technologies like A.I. voice generation and V.R. are warping the boundaries of documentary filmmaking. So how does a veteran like Ken Burns, who has spent over 40 years documenting American history, think about the ethical questions attached to these tools?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The American Canoeist Nevin Harrison Finally Gets Her Chance
description: As women’s canoeing makes its Olympic debut, the 19-year-old is ready to put the United States in the medal hunt in a sport at which the nation has not historically been good.
content: TOKYO — When Nevin Harrison first tried canoe racing at age 12, becoming an Olympian was not the first thing on her mind. Staying out of the water was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Lashbrook
title: Welcome to the Neighborhood. Pay No Attention to Those Men Folding Laundry.
description: In her new novel, “The Husbands,” Chandler Baker turns the Stepford formula upside down.
content: THE HUSBANDSBy Chandler Baker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Alyssa Naeher has left the U.S.-Canada semifinal with a knee injury.
description: The American goalkeeper was the hero of her team’s quarterfinal victory in the Olympic women’s soccer tournament.
content: United States goalkeeper Alyssa Naeher, the hero of her team’s quarterfinal victory in the Olympic women’s soccer tournament, left the team’s semifinal match against Canada on Monday with a knee injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Bollen
title: The Novel That Inspired Harry Styles and Emma Corrin’s Upcoming Film
description: Published in Britain in 2012 but only being released in the United States for the first time now, “My Policeman,” by Bethan Roberts, depicts a passionate love triangle between a married couple and an older gay man in 1950s Brighton.
content: MY POLICEMANBy Bethan Roberts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: He Has a Speedskating Medal. Can He Get One in Baseball, Too?
description: Eddy Alvarez won a silver medal in speedskating in 2014. Now playing baseball, he is hoping to join a rare group with medals from the Summer and Winter Games.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan —  As competition got underway in Tokyo, only 142 athletes in the history of the Games had competed in both the Summer and Winter Olympics. That group is small for obvious reasons. It’s really hard to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain Rethinks Letting China Enter Its Nuclear Power Industry
description: Financing and security issues are clouding new power station projects.
content: LONDON — A few years ago, Britain agreed to let China take an ownership stake in its newest nuclear power plants, figuring Beijing had the nuclear know-how and the construction smarts to help replace the country’s aging power stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Kid Laroi’s Ever-Growing Mixtape Is Now a No. 1 Album
description: By continually adding songs to “____ Love,” the teenage rapper and singer’s label pushed a release that arrived a year ago to the top of the Billboard 200.
content: A year ago, the Kid Laroi, a teenage rapper and singer from Australia, released a debut mixtape, “____ Love,” which opened at No. 8 on the Billboard album chart thanks to a single, “Go,” featuring Juice WRLD, the emo rap star who had died in December 2019 at age 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Workplace vaccine mandates reveal a divide among workers.
description: Corporate requirements for vaccinations have so far tended to cover the white-collar workers, not the lower-income workers on the front lines who are less likely to be vaccinated.
content: The tide has begun to turn on corporate vaccine mandates, with large employers including the Walt Disney Company, Facebook, Google and Walmart introducing stricter requirements for employees returning to the workplace. But the policies come with some important caveats as executives juggle public health, labor relations and the bottom line, the DealBook newsletter reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Sarinsky
title: Stop the Hidden-Fee Rip-Off
description: The Federal Trade Commission should stop sellers from using “drip pricing.”
content: Want to catch a ballgame at Yankee Stadium? Tickets for Sunday’s game against the Seattle Mariners are being advertised by Ticketmaster, the league’s preferred vendor, for as low as $15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: The death toll from flooding in China rises sharply, to more than 300.
description: The total more than tripled since last week, suggesting delays in reporting other deaths.
content: The number of people who died in recent floods in central China has increased dramatically to 302, officials said on Monday, more than tripling the previously reported total and raising questions about the full scale of the disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Elsie Chen
title: With #MeToo Case, China Takes a Swipe at Celebrity Obsession
description: The detention of Kris Wu, a popular Canadian singer, has been hailed as a rare victory for the movement. But Beijing, wary of social activism, has cast it as a warning to celebrities.
content: China’s ruling Communist Party has seized on the high-profile detention of a Canadian Chinese pop singer in Beijing on suspicion of rape to deliver a stark warning against what it regards as a social ill: celebrity obsession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Jade Carey of the United States wins the floor exercise gold.
description: Carey held off Vanessa Ferrari of Italy by performing a more difficult routine.
content: TOKYO — Jade Carey redeemed herself from a disappointing performance in the vault final to come back the next day at the Tokyo Games and win the gold medal on the floor exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: He Sang 2 Songs at an Election Rally. Hong Kong Says He Violated the Law.
description: Anticorruption officials arrested Anthony Wong Yiu-ming, a Cantopop singer, who has publicly supported the Chinese territory’s pro-democracy opposition.
content: HONG KONG — In 2018, the Cantopop singer Anthony Wong Yiu-ming performed two songs at an election rally and encouraged attendees to vote for a pro-democracy candidate for Hong Kong’s legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kai Eide and Tadamichi Yamamoto
title: We Cannot Stand By and Watch Afghanistan Collapse
description: The United Nations must guide the country away from catastrophe.
content: The past few months in Afghanistan, even by the standards set by two decades of war, have been especially calamitous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Wicked’ Hits the Road, Carrying the Hopes of Broadway Tours
description: The production, which starts Tuesday in Dallas, is the first Broadway tour back onstage, a test as American theaters seek to rebound from the pandemic shutdown.
content: DALLAS — Talia Suskauer knows what it’s like to be green. She remembers the feel of pigment and powder on her arms, neck, and face; how the color seemed to seep into her pores and linger behind her ears; what it was like to see a strange but familiar self staring back from a mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: A Track Built for Speed Is Already Producing Records
description: The springy surface at Olympic Stadium in Tokyo has been compared to a trampoline. “You can feel the bounce,” one runner said.
content: TOKYO — The clock stationed just past the finish line flashed 10.60 seconds and the letters “NEW OR,” meaning “new Olympic record,” when Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica won the women’s 100 meters on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Why Migraine Sufferers May Want to Eat More Fish
description: A diet high in omega-3s, the fats found in fish, and low in omega-6s, found in many vegetable oils, led to fewer headaches.
content: For most of her life, Tanya Kamka suffered migraine headaches on a weekly basis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Cryptocurrency in the infrastructure bill: The industry won last-minute concessions.
description: Cryptocurrency lobbyists had expressed alarm at the prospect of far-reaching scrutiny from the I.R.S.
content: A last-minute lobbying push by the cryptocurrency industry to change language in the bipartisan infrastructure bill that was finalized over the weekend succeeded in scaling back some of the scrutiny that participants in the sector will face from the I.R.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Three (White, Male) Tough Guys Sign Off. Is It a Moment?
description: “Bosch,” “Mr. Inbetween” and “Jack Irish,” dependably good and noticeably old-fashioned, all reach the end of the hard-boiled road.
content: Biologists trace changes in the environment through die-offs: a lake of belly-up fish or a sudden drop in the honey bee population. The television ecosphere is less conducive to scientific analysis — the recent arrival of the final episodes of “Bosch,” “Mr. Inbetween” and “Jack Irish” within just over a month could be coincidental. On the other hand, it could be a sign that the climate has become less hospitable to hard-boiled crime dramas with middle-aged white male heroes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen Guitarist’s Flooded London Basement Foretells a Climate Under Pressure
description: After a heat wave and two Southeast Asia-style rainstorms that flooded the capital’s streets, subways and Brian May’s cellar, it seems timely to ask if the city is prepared to deal with wild weather.
content: LONDON — Brian May is best known as the songwriter and guitar god who backed Freddie Mercury in the British band Queen. He has a doctorate in astrophysics and studies asteroids as a hobby. But lately, Mr. May has gotten attention for the kind of earthbound problem that plagues ordinary mortals: a flooded basement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: NYT Games No Longer Available on Across Lite as of Aug. 10
description: Starting next week, we will no longer provide downloadable .puz files.
content: Starting Aug. 10, we will no longer support crossword play on Across Lite in order to focus on editing more puzzles and improving our internal tools and processes This means we won’t provide downloadable .puz files for use on that platform for future or archive puzzles. You can play the NYT crossword on our Crossword App and on desktop and mobile web. We will continue to provide downloadable PDFs for pen-on-paper play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Paying for the infrastructure bill: The plan relies on unused relief money to cover some of the cost.
description: Lawmakers have turned to $200 billion in unused money from previous economic relief programs that Congress approved to combat the pandemic.
content: To pay for the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, lawmakers have turned to $200 billion in unused money from previous economic relief programs that Congress approved to combat the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Nicole Hong
title: In N.Y.C., a push to bring back tourists includes razing homeless encampments.
description: As New York City strives to lure back tourists and office workers, it has undertaken an aggressive campaign to push homeless people off the streets of Manhattan.
content: As New York City strives to lure back tourists and office workers, it has undertaken an aggressive campaign to push homeless people off the streets of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Monday night includes beach volleyball, track and wrestling.
description: USA Network will also air the women’s water polo quarterfinal match between the United States and Canada.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage late on Monday and overnight. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: An Obama Documentary and ‘Shiva Baby’
description: HBO debuts a new docuseries about President Barack Obama. And a claustrophobic comedy blends sexual tension, small talk and brined fish.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 2-8. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: No, Cormac McCarthy Isn’t on Twitter. Don’t Be Fooled by the Check Mark.
description: An account posing as the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “The Road,” “No Country for Old Men” and “All the Pretty Horses” was mistakenly verified by Twitter.
content: The check mark gave it a semblance of legitimacy, but a popular Twitter account associated with Cormac McCarthy, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “The Road” and “No Country for Old Men,” that went from being verified to not is a fake, his agent said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles Will Compete, and Helped Jade Carey Prepare for Gold
description: Biles, who will compete in the balance beam final women’s gymnastics competition of the Tokyo Games, gave Jade Carey a pep talk before Carey won gold in the floor exercise.
content: After failing to win a medal on the vault on Sunday, Jade Carey went back to the U.S. gymnastics team’s hotel and searched for ways to shake off her disappointment. With one more event to go in these Tokyo Games, the floor exercise, she needed to bounce back, and fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, J. David Goodman and William K. Rashbaum
title: Cuomo Grilled for 11 Hours in Sexual Harassment Inquiry
description: The investigation by the New York State attorney general’s office could determine Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s political future.
content: For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the setting and even the circumstances were familiar. He sat at a conference room table at his 39th-floor office in Midtown Manhattan, facing a former federal prosecutor with whom he had tangled before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller and Michael Snyder
title: The 25 Most Significant Works of Postwar Architecture
description: Three architects, three journalists and two designers gathered over Zoom to make a list of the most influential and lasting buildings that have been erected — or cleverly updated — since World War II. Here are the results.
content: A few months ago, I set up a Zoom call with the architects Toshiko Mori, Annabelle Selldorf and Vincent Van Duysen; the designer Tom Dixon; the artist and set designer Es Devlin; the critic and T contributor Nikil Saval; and Tom Delavan, T’s design/interiors director, to talk about postwar architecture. Our goal was to make a list — similar to ones we’ve done on influential rooms, protest art and contemporary art — of the 25 most significant buildings constructed after World War II. The word “significant” always inspires debate, and there was plenty of disagreement among those assembled, but we hoped to surface projects made over the last eight decades anywhere in the world, whether public or private — though we did limit our list to those that are still standing (which, if you consider various oppressive governments, imposed some geographical limitations) — and so we asked each of our panelists to nominate 10 or so entries ahead of time, from which we would mercilessly cull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The South Must Teach Its Children the Truth
description: Attempts to restrict how students are taught about racism in schools have multiplied, but some in the South are standing in defense of real history.
content: NASHVILLE — There was a time when ancestor worship was almost obligatory in the South. The tiniest rural community, hardly more than a red-dirt crossroads, had its own graveyard, and those graves were never short of flowers. Sometimes the flowers were made of faded plastic, but they were always a marker of love, a sign of remembrance, even if the flower bearers knew the dead only from family stories that recalled the best of who they had been in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: ‘Freedom,’ Florida and the Delta Variant Disaster
description: When that word does not mean what you think it means.
content: Ron DeSantis, governor of Florida, isn’t stupid. He is, however, ambitious and supremely cynical. So when he says things that sound stupid it’s worth asking why. And his recent statements on Covid-19 help us understand why so many Americans are still dying or getting severely ill from the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Her Latest Trick: Finding an Affordable One-Bedroom in Manhattan
description: After a year in New Jersey, a fashion designer who moonlights as a magician discovered to her surprise that she could afford to move back to the city.
content: Most people have a junk drawer. Rachel Wax has a magic drawer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins
title: Covax, the vast global vaccination program, struggles to get shots into arms.
description: Deaths from Covid-19 were surging across Africa in June when 100,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in Chad. The delivery seemed proof that Covax, the United Nations-backed program to immunize the world, could get the most desirable vaccines to the least developed countries.
content: Deaths from Covid-19 were surging across Africa in June when 100,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in Chad. The delivery seemed proof that Covax, the United Nations-backed program to immunize the world, could get the most desirable vaccines to the least developed countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: De Blasio urges vaccinated New Yorkers to wear masks indoors but balks at a mandate.
description: The mayor said vaccinated New Yorkers needed to mask up inside because of C.D.C. guidance involving areas of high transmission, but he did not require masks.
content: New York City has seen a rapid rise in coronavirus cases — more than 1,200 cases per day, roughly six times the number in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Olympian Anna Cockrell has a special fan base: the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
description: Anna Cockrell’s brother, Ross, is a cornerback for the team. On Monday, the Buccaneers took a break from training to watch her advance to the 400-meter hurdle finals.
content: On Monday, members of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers took a break from training camp and gathered to watch some game tape. But it wasn’t just any game they were watching: It was the Tokyo 2020 Games, specifically the women’s 400-meter hurdles, an event featuring Anna Cockrell, whose brother, Ross Cockrell, is a cornerback on the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: After a scorching, parched summer across much of the U.S., what will August bring?
description: We’re on top of the latest in extreme weather in the United States, and around the world. Follow along here for heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: Michael Hambrick has been putting out fires for over 25 years. But last month, the Dixie Fire raged so quickly through Plumas County in California that Mr. Hambrick, a helicopter attack firefighter, couldn’t save even his own house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: State Dept. Offers Potential Refugee Status to More Afghans Who Worked With U.S.
description: As the Taliban make territorial gains, more Afghans, including those who helped U.S. news outlets, will become eligible for visas.
content: The State Department is offering potential refugee status to several new categories of Afghans who assisted the United States during the war in Afghanistan, including those who worked for news media and nongovernmental organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Roads in the infrastructure bill: Billions for repair, maintenance and safety.
description: The legislation directs funding toward an expansive backlog of needed repairs and aims to shore up infrastructure to withstand climate change.
content: Much of the bipartisan infrastructure legislation is directed toward roads and bridges: pouring billions of dollars toward an expansive backlog of needed repairs across the country, and shoring up the nation’s highways and infrastructure to withstand the toll of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Looking for St. Mark’s Square? You May Find Yourself in a Shipyard Instead
description: As Venice’s ban on cruise ships took effect this weekend, some tourists were surprised to be docked hours away from the city’s famous sights.
content: MONFALCONE, Italy — Vittoria Comparone had never been to Venice. So for her coming honeymoon, she booked a dream cruise including a majestic approach to the city past St. Mark’s Square, the Doge’s Palace and all the astonishing, photogenic treasures along the Giudecca Canal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Matthew Goldstein
title: The White House calls on states to prevent a crisis after the federal eviction moratorium expired.
description: The Biden administration, in consultation with tenants’ groups, is considering a range of limited actions to blunt the impact of the expiration.
content: With the federal moratorium on evictions having expired over the weekend, the White House on Monday sought to limit the impact, demanding that states speed up disbursement of billions in bottled-up rental aid, while pleading with local governments to immediately enact their own extensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: In Manhattan, Daily Sweeps Target Homeless New Yorkers
description: The approach to persuading  people to go to shelters — used heavily  since the pandemic started — is ineffective, critics say.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Aubry Kaplan
title: I No Longer Want to Shop
description: A year without retail therapy changed my attitude toward shopping.
content: As Covid-19 vaccinations began to open up the world for some of us in pandemic-battered Los Angeles, going back to restaurants, dance clubs, bars or theaters was at the top of many wish lists. But at the top of mine was going back to malls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Welcome to His World. And Hers.
description: In a mixed but audacious first season, AMC’s feminist deconstruction of marriage stories made two sets of TV clichés into something bigger.
content: In Disney+’s “WandaVision,” sitcoms were a prison and a haven. The Avengers’ Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen), racked with grief over the death of her android husband, Vision (Paul Bettany), conjured him back to life on a sitcom set — a magical bubble constructed of made-for-TV happy memories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Jasmine Camacho-Quinn wins the 100-meter hurdles, Puerto Rico’s first gold in track.
description: It’s also Puerto Rico’s second Olympic gold medal in any sport.
content: TOKYO — Jasmine Camacho-Quinn of Puerto Rico won the women’s 100-meter hurdles on Monday morning, beating Kendra Harrison of the United States, the world-record holder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: The App With the Unprintable Name That Wants to Give Power to Creators
description: Fed up with the imbalance between online influencers and brands, Lindsey Lee Lugrin and Isha Mehra created a platform to change that.
content: LOS ANGELES — Six years ago, Lindsey Lee Lugrin, a budding social media creator and model, was given the chance to be featured in a Marc by Marc Jacobs ad campaign. She was paid $1,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Will You Know if Your Co-workers Are Vaccinated? Tell Us About It.
description: Policies on returning to work are in flux as employers confront questions of privacy, health and safety. We’re curious to know your thoughts.
content: As millions of Americans prepare to return to their jobs in person, many employers are scrambling to implement health and safety protocols in the workplace, whether that is an office, on the front lines, or anywhere else. Reporters for The New York Times writing about these policies would like to hear from workers about their experiences. (And throughout the pandemic, millions of workers never left their workplaces. We’re interested in hearing from people returning to non-office or office-support jobs, too. Please share your experiences here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Here’s what happened on Monday at the Tokyo Games.
description: The U.S. women’s soccer team is out of contention for the gold. The U.S. women’s basketball team is past the group phase, and Puerto Rico won its second gold medal ever.
content: The best that the World Cup-winning U.S. women’s soccer team can do at these Games now is a bronze medal. The team lost to Canada, 1-0, on Monday in the semifinal. It was a measure of revenge for Canada, which lost a classic semifinal to the U.S. at the 2012 Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Sydney Ember
title: Lack of Foreign Workers Has Seasonal Businesses Scrambling
description: Even with a visa cap increased, the pandemic’s disruption has left a dearth of landscapers, crabbers and restaurant help.
content: SALT LAKE CITY — Tyler Holt summed up the problem his Utah landscaping business faces every year. “People who want to be in the job force want stability — if they want to work, they work full time,” he said. “Locally there’s just no workers who want to do anything seasonal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: 12-Hour Days, Six Days a Week
description: Today, Vivian Wang explains Chinese work culture and the debate around working conditions.
content: To understand work culture in China, start with a number: 996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates finalize their divorce
description: Details of how the couple split their assets were not made public. The couple was married for 27 years.
content: The divorce between Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates is now final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. Falls to Canada, a Stinging Blow in a Frustrating Olympics
description: A second-half penalty kick sends Canada to the gold medal game, and leaves the U.S. seeking the bronze, and answers.
content: KASHIMA, Japan — The referee’s whistle had barely finished chirping when the Canadian players sprinted to the middle of the field and unleashed an explosion of exaltation that echoed around an otherwise silent stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Vaccines, Infrastructure, Olympics: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Administration to Keep Using Public Health Rule to Turn Away Migrants
description: Citing new concerns about the spread of the coronavirus, the administration will continue to rely for now on a Trump-era policy.
content: WASHINGTON — With the number of migrants crossing the southern border surging and the pandemic proving to be far from over, the Biden administration has decided to leave in place for now the public health rule that has allowed it to turn away hundreds of thousands of migrants, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Homeowners without traditional mortgages are eligible for federal aid.
description: The Treasury Department expanded its guidance to allow states to use the $10 billion Homeowner Assistance Fund to help those with nontraditional home loans.
content: States can allocate some of the $10 billion in federal funding for struggling homeowners to help people who bought their residences with nontraditional home loans, according to Treasury Department officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Florida may face its worst wave ever as Delta variant spreads.
description: The state is about a month away from its peak, according to an epidemiologist who tracks the virus there.
content: As the highly contagious Delta variant of the virus rips through the unvaccinated population in the United States, Florida is heading toward its worst outbreak since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Broadband in the infrastructure bill: Taking aim at the digital divide.
description: The legislation contains $65 billion to connect rural communities and low-income urban residents who cannot afford high-speed internet service.
content: Lawmakers have bemoaned the nation’s nagging digital divide for years, warning that gaps in broadband internet access in red and blue states alike are hurting Americans’ health, education and job prospects. The hulking bipartisan infrastructure package before the Senate this week would try to finally slam it shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Oyler
title: Start-Ups Are Not Great for Marriages
description: New novels by Tahmima Anam and Y.Z. Chin feature South Asian American women facing disadvantages in tech.
content: THE STARTUP WIFE By Tahmima Anam
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal and Glenn Kramon
title: Don’t Want a Vaccine? Be Prepared to Pay More for Insurance.
description: Health insurers could do more to encourage vaccination, including letting the unvaccinated foot their bills.
content: America’s Covid-19 vaccination rate is at around 60 percent, for ages twelve and up. That’s not enough to reach so-called herd immunity, and in states like Missouri — where a number of counties have vaccination rates under 25 percent — hospitals are overwhelmed by serious outbreaks of the more contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Beauty, Athleticism and Danger in the Pool
description: Artistic swimmers strive to look graceful, but the sport comes with significant risks, as our writer knows from experience.
content: WALNUT CREEK, CALIF. — When the artistic swimming team competition begins Friday at the Tokyo Games, the swimmers’ goal will be to make their movements appear effortless. But while viewers will see smiling performers, sparkly suits and gelatin-slicked hair, a risk lurks beneath the surface: the potential for concussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: The U.S. finally hits its 70 percent vaccination goal — four weeks late.
description: States with low vaccination rates are seeing more people seeking out the shots as the Delta variant creates a new wave of cases.
content: The United States on Monday finally reached President Biden’s goal of having 70 percent of eligible adults at least partly vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: It Was His Day Off. Then the Space Station Went for a Spin.
description: Zebulon Scoville and others at NASA’s mission control in Houston spent Thursday righting the International Space Station after a new Russian module unexpectedly fired its thrusters.
content: The International Space Station, with a mass of more than 900,000 pounds and spanning an area as large as a football field, is not designed to do back flips like an Olympic gymnast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 2, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 2, 2021.
content: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the admiration across Venezuela’s political spectrum for Dr. José Gregorio Hernández, a doctor recently beatified by the Vatican, referred incorrectly to his status in the church. While he has been beatified (putting him on the path to sainthood), he has not yet been canonized and is not yet a saint. The error was repeated in a front page summary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Lynn C. Franklin, Literary Agent and Memoirist on Adoption, Dies at 74
description: She represented Desmond Tutu and Deepak Chopra, but the book closest to her was the one she wrote about giving up her baby and then reuniting with him.
content: Lynn C. Franklin, a literary scout and agent whose clients included Archbishop Desmond Tutu and who made a mark with her own book, in which she shared her personal story about giving up her son for adoption in the 1960s, died on July 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Despite social media bans, Trump has been the G.O.P.’s top fund-raiser this year.
description: Despite departing from office and being barred from the leading social media platforms, former President Donald J. Trump was the Republican Party’s most dominant fund-raiser in the first half of 2021 and ended June with a war chest of more than $100 million, according to new federal campaign filings made this weekend.
content: Despite departing from office and being barred from the leading social media platforms, former President Donald J. Trump was the Republican Party’s most dominant fund-raiser in the first half of 2021 and ended June with a war chest of more than $100 million, according to new federal campaign filings made this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: French protests over Covid passes.
content: For the third week in a row, thousands took to the streets across France to protest the government’s health pass law, which bars those without proof of vaccination or a recent negative test for Covid-19 from many indoor venues. It was passed by Parliament but still needs a final greenlight from a top constitutional council, expected next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Tariq Panja
title: Belarusian Sprinter Who Feared for Her Safety Is Offered Asylum in Poland
description: Kristina Timanovskaya sought help at a Tokyo airport as her country tried to forcibly send her home from the Olympics.
content: TOKYO — Kristina Timanovskaya, the Belarusian Olympic sprinter who sought protection at a Tokyo airport as her nation tried to forcibly send her home from the Summer Games, has been offered asylum in Poland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The workplace mandate gap.
content: As the highly contagious Delta variant drives up cases across the country, more companies are announcing vaccine mandates for workers, including Disney, Walmart, Google and The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.5 Million Homes in California
description: A modern farmhouse in Ventura, a three-bedroom home in West Hollywood and a six-acre retreat with dramatic water views near Mendocino.
content: Six of this property’s nearly 13 acres are planted with avocado trees, and there is a citrus grove, as well. The lot, nestled in the hills overlooking the coastline, is private, with no neighboring homes in sight. But it is well located for visiting surrounding areas: Rincon Point, a beach on the border of Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties, with some of the country’s best surfing, is 20 minutes away; about 40 minutes in the opposite direction is Ojai, a popular resort destination and wine-industry hub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Solving the Mystery of I.B.S.
description: Experts are starting to untangle the biological underpinnings of this common yet perplexing disorder. What they’re finding could offer clues on how to treat it.
content: No one with debilitating symptoms likes to be told “it’s all in your head.” Yet, this is often what distressed patients with irritable bowel syndrome hear, implicitly or explicitly, when a medical work-up reveals no apparent explanation for their repeated bouts of abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea or constipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Alexandra Leigh Young, Jessica Cheung, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow and Chris Wood
title: A New Chapter of the Coronavirus
description: What do breakthrough infections mean for efforts to fight the pandemic?
content: The C.D.C.’s recent investigation of a coronavirus outbreak in Provincetown, Mass., in which most of those infected had been immunized is changing the way many are approaching the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Léontine Gallois
title: Pfizer and Moderna raised their vaccine prices in their latest E.U contracts.
description: Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna both increased the price of their coronavirus vaccines in their latest contracts with the European Union, France’s minister for European affairs said on Monday.
content: Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna both increased the price of their coronavirus vaccines in their latest contracts with the European Union, France’s minister for European affairs said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: George Forss, 80, Photographer Discovered on the Streets of N.Y., Dies
description: He was peddling his black-and-white photos of New York City’s majesty for $5 each in the 1980s — until a famous photographer came upon them in “astonishment.”
content: In the 1980s, a street photographer named George Forss was selling his black-and-white pictures of the Empire State Building and Central Park to tourists for $5 a pop. Like so many of New York’s sidewalk peddlers, he was just trying to make a buck. But his images stood apart from the typical fare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Paula Caplan, 74, Dies; Feminist Psychologist Took On Her Profession
description: She argued that categorizing premenstrual syndrome or feelings of guilt as disorders resulted from sexism in a field dominated by men.
content: Paula Caplan, a pioneering psychologist who exposed how her profession had pathologized a wide range of female traits and social responsibilities, including motherhood, menstruation and even shopping, died on July 21 at her home in Rockville, Md. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With a Door Left Open, Atlanta Hopes to Walk Right In
description: An unassuming Braves trade kicked off a frenzy of moves leaguewide. It sent a message that the Mets or Phillies can’t have the N.L. East title without a fight.
content: It was the ripple before the typhoon, the start of the wildest late-July swap meet in baseball history. On July 15, the last day of the All-Star break, Alex Anthopoulos, the general manager of the Atlanta Braves, dealt a prospect to the Chicago Cubs for outfielder Joc Pederson. By the end of the month, 158 players — including some of the biggest names in baseball — had been traded, and all 30 teams had made at least one move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Amtrak in the infrastructure bill: $66 billion in new funding, and an adjusted mandate.
description: The new funding would be the largest investment in passenger rail since Amtrak was created in 1971, according to the administration.
content: President Biden frequently mentions his fondness for Amtrak, which began in the 1970s, when he would travel home from Washington to Delaware every night to care for his two sons after his wife and infant daughter were killed in a car crash. Mr. Biden, who took an estimated 8,000 round trips on the line, has pledged to inject billions in rail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Montgomery
title: A 17-year-old sprinter from Tampa, Fla., is the youngest Olympic track competitor for the U.S.
description: Erriyon Knighton broke Usain Bolt’s under-18 record in the 200 meters in May and surpassed Bolt’s under-20 record in June, and he beat reigning world champion Noah Lyles in two races at the Olympic trials.
content: On the Olympic track, 17-year-old Erriyon Knighton is a sensation. He broke Usain Bolt’s under-18 record in the 200 meters in May and surpassed Bolt’s under-20 record in June, and he beat reigning world champion Noah Lyles, 24, in two races at the Olympic trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: As Bang on a Can Returns, a New Generation Rises
description: After months of livestreamed marathons, the new music collective was back to in-person performance with a two-day festival.
content: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. — Venturing back to live performances and finding a classical music institution in rude health can be like putting on a pair of old jeans and discovering, with relief, an easy fit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Are You Planning a European Trip? Prepare for a Welter of Virus Rules.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 2, 2021.
content: “Chances are things are going to change or something is going to go wrong, and you need to be OK with that reality before you decide to travel internationally.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Schools in the infrastructure bill: Money for cleaner drinking water and greener buses.
description: Billions each year would be allocated to grants to remove lead-contaminated pipes in the nation’s schools.
content: The $1 trillion infrastructure bill under consideration in the Senate includes billions of dollars dedicated to benefiting public schools and children, including funding for replacing lead pipes, upgrading school buses and making it easier for kids to walk to school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Jeré Longman
title: The World’s Best Pole-Vaulter Gets More Swedish as He Goes
description: Mondo Duplantis has a world record and a good chance at Olympic gold. But he’s endeared himself to Sweden (his mother’s home country) by buying into its culture.
content: TOKYO — Mondo Duplantis was a high school freshman when his life changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Corporate Vaccine Gap
description: Partial mandates at Walmart and others may widen a class divide.
content: The tide has begun to turn on corporate vaccine mandates, with companies including Disney, Facebook, Google and Walmart recently introducing stricter requirements for employees returning to the workplace. But the policies come with some important caveats as executives juggle public health, labor relations and the bottom line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Nicole Hong
title: New York Is Pushing Homeless People Off the Streets. Where Will They Go?
description: Cleanup crews are clearing encampments, but advocates say the sweeps just move people from one place to another and fail to address the housing crisis.
content: On a sweltering July afternoon, a homeless man named Melvin Douglas biked up to his sleeping spot beneath the High Line, the elevated, art-filled New York park overlooking the Hudson River, and found that a city cleanup crew had thrown away his possessions — again. The same thing had happened the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: U.S. Athletes Have Been Planning Podium Protests for Weeks
description: Raven Saunders, a shot-putter, on Sunday delivered the first political demonstration at the Games. The I.O.C. and American officials are now locked in a standoff.
content: TOKYO — Raven Saunders, the American shot-putter who delivered the first political demonstration on the podium at the Tokyo Olympics when she raised her arms and crossed them in the shape of an X shortly after receiving her silver medal, said Monday that American athletes have been planning their protest in defiance of International Olympic Committee regulations for several weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Berry
title: Charting the Course of Tokyo’s Climbing Walls
description: The eccentric architects behind the Olympic debut of sport climbing are responsible for putting on a good show, and a fair competition.
content: The climbing routes debuting at the Tokyo Games have never been seen before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Nicholas Fandos
title: Senator Lindsey Graham says he has a breakthrough Covid infection.
description: The positive test result raised concerns that other senators may have been exposed at a party hosted by Senator Manchin over the weekend.
content: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina announced on Monday that he had tested positive for Covid-19 and that his symptoms have been mild, which he attributed to having received the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Billie Eilish’s Uneasy View From the Top
description: On her second album, “Happier Than Ever,” the 19-year-old pop phenomenon takes on new anxieties and adversaries — and debates just how much of herself to reveal.
content: Billie Eilish has a voice full of secrets. She is known for rarely raising its volume higher than an ASMR-triggering whisper, but there’s also a certain taunting knowingness in its tone. Consider the withering “duh” that punctuates her breakout smash “Bad Guy” — if you don’t get it by now, she seems to be saying with an audible eye-roll, she’ll never tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Azi Paybarah
title: Jay Pickett, Veteran Soap Opera Actor, Dies at 60
description: His credits included “General Hospital,” “Days of Our Lives” and “Port Charles.” He died while filming a western in Idaho, where he was raised.
content: Jay Pickett, an actor known for his roles in TV soap operas like “General Hospital” and “Days of Our Lives,” died on Friday while filming a movie in Idaho. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Sifan Hassan wins the 5,000 meters and now looks to the 1,500 and 10,000.
description: Winning medals in all three events would secure Hassan’s place as one of the great distance runners in Olympic history.
content: TOKYO — One gold medal down. Two to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: 2 House Races in Ohio Will Test Democratic Divisions and Trump’s Sway
description: In the Cleveland area, a bitter primary election is pitting the left against the Democratic establishment. Near Columbus, a Trump-endorsed candidate faces a crowded Republican field.
content: Two primary contests on Tuesday for open House seats in Ohio will act as a stress test for both Democrats and Republicans, offering early hints about whether party leaders are aligned with their voters ahead of the midterm elections next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins
title: Where a Vast Global Vaccination Program Went Wrong
description: After months of struggle, the U.N.-backed Covax alliance will soon have many more doses, promising relief for vaccine shortages in poorer countries. But it faces a deepening crisis: difficulties getting shots into arms as the Delta variant spreads.
content: Deaths from Covid-19 were surging across Africa in June when 100,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in Chad. The delivery seemed proof that the United Nations-backed program to immunize the world could get the most desirable vaccines to the least developed nations. Yet five weeks later, Chad’s health minister said, 94,000 doses remained unused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stirn
title: Fleeting Glimpses of Indonesia’s Endangered Orangutans
description: On the island of Sumatra, a devoted group of conservationists is grasping for a solution that will benefit both the animals and the people who live around them.
content: We watched in silence as the two orangutans, a mother and her child, prepared themselves for an encroaching rainstorm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Delta Variant in Schools: What to Know
description: Classrooms are opening their doors to a different pandemic. Here is how to think about risk.
content: Last week, in what was intended to be an internal document, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention made a stark admission: The highly contagious Delta variant had redrawn the battle lines of the coronavirus pandemic, necessitating new public health measures like universal mask mandates. Or, as the agency put it in the document, which was obtained by The New York Times, “the war has changed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: Mask Mandates Are Returning in Many Cities. N.Y.C. Is Holding Back.
description: Louisiana and San Francisco brought back indoor mask requirements, but Mayor Bill de Blasio said he wanted New Yorkers to focus on vaccinations.
content: With the Delta variant of the coronavirus surging, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York on Monday stopped short of reinstating an indoor mask mandate even as more cities and at least one state did so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump plans to fight the release of his tax returns to Congress.
description: “We’re going to fight this tooth and nail,” said a lawyer for the former president.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump plans to fight the release of his tax returns to Congress, a lawyer for Mr. Trump said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: How Covax went wrong.
content: The multibillion-dollar alliance of international health systems and nonprofits was supposed to ensure that poor countries received vaccines as quickly as rich ones. Instead, Covax struggled in its attempts to secure doses, falling half a billion short of its target, and is now failing to actually deliver the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: You, too, can have an Olympic medal (for the right price).
description: A silver medal in shooting from the 1900 Olympics in Paris recently sold for a mere $1,283.
content: A silver medal in shooting from the 1900 Olympics in Paris recently sold for a mere $1,283.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Climate in the infrastructure bill: A substantial investment in resilience.
description: The legislation contains what could be the largest investment in climate resilience in American history.
content: As the United States staggers through another year of devastating wildfires, drought, storms and other calamities, the infrastructure bill before Congress would pour major resources into a response. The measure agreed to over the weekend includes billions of dollars to better prepare the country for the effects of global warming, in what could be the largest investment in climate resilience in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Haitians Investigating President’s Death, Under Threat, Go Into Hiding
description: The officials, two court clerks and an investigative judge who collected evidence in President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination, are now in hiding.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — They examined the bodies of Haiti’s slain president and of the mercenaries who are accused of conspiring to kill him. Now they are in hiding, changing their location every few hours, with a backpack full of legal documents that could determine the fate of Haiti’s most important trial in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Tariq Panja
title: In Weight Lifting, a Historic Moment for Transgender Women
description: A sport that rarely makes headlines was at the center of the Olympics on Monday as the first openly transgender woman competed in the Games.
content: TOKYO — A niche sport in the best of times, weight lifting has in recent years often made news for the wrong reasons, including doping scandals and widespread corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: The Bootleg Fire in Oregon is 84 percent contained, officials say.
description: Several days of rain have helped in the fight against the fire, which has consumed more than 400,000 acres.
content: The destructive Bootleg Fire in Oregon, which was ignited by lightning in early July and has grown to more than 400,000 acres, now appears to be mostly contained, after recent weather conditions helped firefighters gain the upper hand on the blaze, state officials announced.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Not-So-Simple Majority
description: We take it for granted that the majority calls the shots. But in one NY school district, that idea — majority rules — has led to an all-out war.
content: We take it for granted that the majority calls the shots. But in one NY school district, that idea — majority rules — has led to an all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeing Yourself In the Wild
description: Stories of those unexpected moments when we see who we really are.
content: Stories of those unexpected moments when we see who we really are.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Things I Mean to Know
description: Of course the earth revolves around the sun. Of course my dog loves me. But how exactly do we know? Stories of people trying to unspool some of life’s certainties, and what they find.
content: Of course the earth revolves around the sun. Of course my dog loves me. But how exactly do we know? Stories of people trying to unspool some of life’s certainties, and what they find.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Have to Live Like a Refugee
description: Stories of refugees in Greece trying to move on with their lives in whatever way they can.
content: Stories of refugees in Greece trying to move on with their lives in whatever way they can.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Choosing Wrong
description: Stories of people making the wrong choice, even though the right one is staring them squarely in the eye.
content: Stories of people making the wrong choice, even though the right one is staring them squarely in the eye.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trail of Tears
description: The writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister re-trace the “Trail of Tears” — the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson.
content: The writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister re-trace the “Trail of Tears” — the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Private Geography
description: Everyone walks around on their own private map of the world — the places we’re from and how they made us — whether we like it or not.
content: Everyone walks around on their own private map of the world — the places we’re from and how they made us — whether we like it or not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Escape From the Lab
description: What happens when our most ingenious creations actually make it out into the world.
content: What happens when our most ingenious creations actually make it out into the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Damned If You Do…
description: It’s one thing to weigh pros and cons. But sometimes all you have is con and con. In this episode, stories of people having to make a choice, when no good options exist.
content: It’s one thing to weigh pros and cons. But sometimes all you have is con and con. In this episode, stories of people having to make a choice, when no good options exist.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Beginning of Now
description: Before Trump started his presidential campaign, there was a congressional race that redefined what was possible in American politics.
content: Before Trump started his presidential campaign, there was a congressional race that redefined what was possible in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Unreality of Now
description: Election officials combat a contagion among their very own workers; people who've never owned guns suddenly go buy them; and two women who allege they were sexually assaulted by the president compare notes.
content: Election officials combat a contagion among their very own workers; people who've never owned guns suddenly go buy them; and two women who allege they were sexually assaulted by the president compare notes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Get Over It!
description: Three stories of people trying to forget the past and move on.
content: Three stories of people trying to forget the past and move on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: I Am Not a Pirate
description: Hold fast, mateys! Stories about both historical and modern-day swashbucklers who loot, pillage, and question their choices.
content: Hold fast, mateys! Stories about both historical and modern-day swashbucklers who loot, pillage, and question their choices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Secret Identity
description: A bank robber on an undercover mission. A teenage girl with the powers of a tiger. A vigilante seeking vengeance in Ciudad Juarez. All have secret identities. But not all of them chose those identities for themselves.
content: A bank robber on an undercover mission. A teenage girl with the powers of a tiger. A vigilante seeking vengeance in Ciudad Juarez. All have secret identities. But not all of them chose those identities for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lockup
description: As the number of prisoners in the United States was rising rapidly, This American Life found stories of their lives and the lives of their families and children.
content: As the number of prisoners in the United States was rising rapidly, This American Life found stories of their lives and the lives of their families and children.
source.name: The New York Times

title: I'm From the Private Sector and I'm Here to Help
description: Private contractors were a part of the Iraq War in unprecedented numbers, but we didn't know that much about the people doing these jobs — why they chose to come to Iraq, and what they saw that we couldn't.
content: Private contractors were a part of the Iraq War in unprecedented numbers, but we didn't know that much about the people doing these jobs — why they chose to come to Iraq, and what they saw that we couldn't.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Administration Pushes States to Prevent Eviction Crisis
description: White House officials called on state governments to extend local moratoriums on evictions and accelerate the distribution of billions in rental aid, to soften the impact of the federal moratorium’s expiration on Saturday.

title: State Dept. Increases Refugee Visas for Some Afghans
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken announced that the State Department would expand its potential refugee status to new categories of Afghans who assisted the U.S. during the war in Afghanistan.

title: De Blasio Urges Vaccinated New Yorkers to Wear Masks Indoors

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Between Melissa Clark’s new recipes for skewers and Dawn Perry’s pies, you’ll have a perfect feast.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark is in The Times this week with an invaluable guide to one of the world’s most versatile — and sometimes tricky — methods of live-fire cookery: grilling with skewers.
